chapters.title: Lesson 1: Кои сме – што сме

grammarNotes.title: Сегашно време (презент)
grammarNotes.content: Present tense in Macedonian conjugates verbs by person and number. Two main verb groups: -а verbs (работа, чита) and -и verbs (зборува, учи). Used for current actions, habits, and general truths.

grammarNotes.title: Членување (Definite Article)
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian has a unique tripartite definite article system that attaches to the end of nouns. The basic article (-от/-та/-то) indicates definiteness, while -ов/-ва/-во (proximal) indicates nearness to the speaker and -он/-на/-но (distal) indicates distance. This three-way distinction is a distinctive feature of Macedonian among Slavic languages.

grammarNotes.title: Придавки од географски имиња (Geographic Adjectives)
grammarNotes.content: Adjectives derived from geographic names follow regular patterns in Macedonian. Add -ски/-ска/-ско to place names to create adjectives. These adjectives agree in gender with the noun they modify, just like regular adjectives. They are commonly used for nationalities, languages, and regional descriptions.

grammarNotes.title: Прашални реченици
grammarNotes.content: Questions in Macedonian use question words (што, кој, каде, кога, како, зошто, колку) or the particle "дали" for yes/no questions. Word order is flexible.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголот "сум"
grammarNotes.content: Present tense in Macedonian conjugates verbs by person and number. Two main verb groups: -а verbs (работа, чита) and -и verbs (зборува, учи). Used for current actions, habits, and general truths.

chapters.intro: Who are we and what do we do? This intermediate lesson dives into identity and nationality. Master present tense verbs, learn how Macedonian articles work (the unique post-positioned definite article), and form adjectives from place names.

chapters.title: Lesson 2: Градот на мојата душа и душата на мојот град
chapters.titleMk: Лекција 2: Градот на мојата душа и душата на мојот град

grammarNotes.title: Да-конструкција (Da-construction)
grammarNotes.content: The да-construction is used with modal verbs (сакам, можам, мора, треба) and replaces infinitives found in other Slavic languages. The structure is: modal verb + да + conjugated verb. Both verbs must agree with the subject. This is one of the Balkan linguistic features shared with Greek and Bulgarian.
examples: Сакам да читам. - I want to read.
Можам да пишувам. - I can write.
Мора да одам. - I must go.
Треба да учиш. - You should study.
Не сакам да спијам. - I don't want to sleep.
Таа сака да пее. - She wants to sing.

grammarNotes.title: Бројни придавки со редно значење
grammarNotes.content: Ordinal numbers in Macedonian are adjectives and agree in gender with the noun. Formed by adding -в/-ва/-во (first), -ри/-ра/-ро (second), or -ти/-та/-то for larger numbers.

grammarNotes.title: Кратки заменски форми (Clitic Pronouns)
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian has short (clitic) and long forms for object pronouns. Short forms (ме, те, го, ја, не, ве, ги) attach to verbs and are used in everyday speech. Long forms (мене, тебе, него, неа, нас, вас, нив) are used for emphasis. Clitic doubling (using both) is common in Macedonian.
examples: Мене ме гледа. - He sees ME (emphatic).
Му давам книга. - I give him a book.

grammarNotes.title: Идно време (Future Tense)
grammarNotes.content: The Macedonian future tense is formed with the particle "ќе" + present tense verb. The particle does not change; only the verb conjugates for person and number. This is a Balkan linguistic feature, distinct from other Slavic languages that use будам + infinitive. Negation: нема да + verb.
examples: Нема да одам. - I will not go.
Утре ќе учам. - Tomorrow I will study.

grammarNotes.title: Прилози (адверби)
grammarNotes.content: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. Types include manner (брзо, полека), time (сега, утре), place (тука, таму), and degree (многу, малку). Most are invariable.

grammarNotes.title: Предлози (препозиции)
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian prepositions indicate spatial, temporal, and abstract relationships. Key prepositions: во (in), на (on/at), со (with), од (from), за (for), до (to/until), по (after/along).
translatedExamples: The book is on the table.

grammarNotes.title: Именки
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian nouns have three genders (masculine, feminine, neuter) which affect article attachment, adjective agreement, and plural formation. Gender is typically predictable from noun endings.

chapters.intro: Explore cities and places close to your heart. Learn the 'да-construction' for expressing desires and intentions, ordinal numbers, and both direct and indirect object pronouns. Perfect for describing your favorite urban landscapes.

chapters.title: Lesson 3: Нејзиното височество – храната

grammarNotes.title: Заповеден начин (императив)
grammarNotes.content: The imperative mood expresses commands, requests, and advice. Forms: 2nd singular (-ј/-и), 2nd plural (-јте/-ете), 1st plural (да + present). Negative imperative uses "не" or "немој(те)".

grammarNotes.title: Глаголска л-форма
grammarNotes.content: The L-form is the past participle used in compound tenses (perfect, pluperfect). Formed by adding -л/-ла/-ло/-ле to the verb stem. Agrees in gender and number with the subject.
examples: Во тоа време често се селеа , а неколку месеци живееја и на село.
Употребете ја глаголската форма за идно време со значење на минатост.
Во градот на липите се сретнаа двапати, за жал, третпат не се случи.
Долго одлучуваа каде да го поминат викендот, на крај ништо не одлучија.
translatedExamples: At that time, they often moved, and lived in the countryside for several months.
Use the future tense verb form with a past meaning.
They met twice in the city of lindens, unfortunately, the third time did not happen.
They spent a long time deciding where to spend the weekend, in the end they decided nothing.

grammarNotes.title: Можен начин / Потенцијал (Conditional)
grammarNotes.content: The Macedonian conditional (potential mood) expresses hypothetical situations, wishes, or polite requests. It is formed with "би" + the л-form of the verb (past participle). The form of "би" does not change for person. This construction corresponds to English "would" constructions.
examples: Би сакал да дојдам. - I would like to come.
Би можел да помогнам. - I could help.
Што би направил? - What would you do?
Би било убаво. - It would be nice.

grammarNotes.title: Модални зборови и изрази
grammarNotes.content: Modal words express necessity (мора, треба), possibility (може), desire (сака), and ability (умее). They combine with da-constructions to express nuanced meanings.

grammarNotes.title: Броеви
grammarNotes.content: Ordinal numbers in Macedonian are adjectives and agree in gender with the noun. Formed by adding -в/-ва/-во (first), -ри/-ра/-ро (second), or -ти/-та/-то for larger numbers.

chapters.intro: Her Majesty - Food! Advance your culinary vocabulary with imperative commands for recipes, past participles, and the conditional mood. From cooking instructions to restaurant recommendations, become fluent in food talk.

chapters.title: Lesson 4: Во светот на купувањето

grammarNotes.title: Минато определено несвршено време (имперфект)
grammarNotes.content: The imperfect describes past ongoing, habitual, or repeated actions. Formed by adding imperfect endings to the verb stem. Emphasizes duration or repetition in the past.
examples: Тој работеше секој ден. (He used to work)
Ние живеевме во Скопје. (We were living)
Тие одеа на училиште. (They went/were going)
translatedExamples: I was reading a book. (I was reading)
He worked every day. (He used to work)
We lived in Skopje. (We were living)
She was always singing. (She always sang)
They went to school. (They went/were going)
While I was eating, the phone rang.

grammarNotes.title: Минато определено свршено време (аорист)
grammarNotes.content: The aorist describes completed past actions witnessed by the speaker. Formed with aorist endings. Used for single, completed events. Contrasts with imperfect (ongoing) and perfect (reported).
examples: Тој купи нова кола. (He bought a new car)
Ние видовме филм. (We saw a film)
Таа отиде на работа. (She went to work)
Тие испеаа песна. (They sang a song)
translatedExamples: He bought a new car. (He bought a new car)
We saw a movie. (We saw a film)
She went to work. (She went to work)
They sang a song. (They sang a song)

grammarNotes.title: Глаголска придавка
grammarNotes.content: Verbal adjectives are formed from verbs and function as adjectives. Two types: active (-чки from -е verbs) and passive (-н/-т). They agree with the noun in gender and number.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголска сум-конструкција (Sum-construction)
grammarNotes.content: The sum-construction combines the verb "сум" (to be) with the passive participle (-н/-т form) to express states resulting from actions. This is similar to the English "is + past participle" structure. The participle agrees in gender and number with the subject.
examples: Вратата е отворена. - The door is open.
Книгата е прочитана. - The book has been read.
Јадењето е подготвено. - The food is prepared.
Писмото е напишано. - The letter is written.
Собата е исчистена. - The room is cleaned.
Работата е завршена. - The work is finished.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголска именка (Verbal Noun)
grammarNotes.content: Verbal nouns are formed from verbs and function as nouns, similar to English gerunds (-ing forms). In Macedonian, they are formed with -ње/-ение endings. They are always neuter gender and can take articles and modifiers like regular nouns.
examples: Читањето е важно. - Reading is important.
Ми се допаѓа пливањето. - I like swimming.

grammarNotes.title: Индиректен предмет (Indirect Object)
grammarNotes.content: The indirect object receives the action indirectly, typically answering "to whom" or "for whom". In Macedonian, short dative pronouns (ми, ти, му, ѝ, ни, ви, им) mark the indirect object. Clitic doubling is common: "Нему му давам" (To him, I give him).
examples: Тој ми дава книга. - He gives me a book.
Јас ти раскажувам приказна. - I tell you a story.
Таа му пишува писмо. - She writes him a letter.
Ние ѝ помагаме. - We help her.
Им кажувам вистината. - I tell them the truth.
Нему му се допаѓа музиката. - He likes the music.

grammarNotes.title: Реален услов
grammarNotes.content: Real conditional expresses likely or possible conditions using "ако" (if) + present/future. The condition is realistic and the result is probable if the condition is met.
examples: Ќе одиме на излет ако е убаво.
translatedExamples: If you study, you will pass.
If I have time, I will come.
If it rains, we will sit at home.
We'll go on a picnic if it's nice.
If you want, you can come.
If you see him, tell him.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголот што
grammarNotes.content: Present tense in Macedonian conjugates verbs by person and number. Two main verb groups: -а verbs (работа, чита) and -и verbs (зборува, учи). Used for current actions, habits, and general truths.
examples: Речениците ќе претрпат и други измени.
Да, доколку порталите ја гарантираат заштитата на моите лични податоци.
Да, доколку е гарантирана заштитата на моите лични податоци.
Да, тоа се проверени системи со меѓународни стандарди.
translatedExamples: The sentences will also undergo other changes.
Yes, if the portals guarantee the protection of my personal data.
Yes, if the protection of my personal data is guaranteed.
Yes, these are proven systems with international standards.

grammarNotes.title: Именки
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian nouns have three genders (masculine, feminine, neuter) which affect article attachment, adjective agreement, and plural formation. Gender is typically predictable from noun endings.

grammarNotes.title: Придавки
grammarNotes.content: Adjectives derived from geographical names follow regular adjective patterns with -ски/-ска/-ско endings. They agree in gender with the noun they modify.

grammarNotes.title: Броеви
grammarNotes.content: Ordinal numbers in Macedonian are adjectives and agree in gender with the noun. Formed by adding -в/-ва/-во (first), -ри/-ра/-ро (second), or -ти/-та/-то for larger numbers.

chapters.intro: Enter the world of shopping with advanced past tenses. Master the imperfect for ongoing past actions, aorist for completed events, and verbal adjectives. Essential grammar for storytelling about shopping experiences.

chapters.title: Lesson 5: Професијата – сон или реалност

grammarNotes.title: Минато неопределено време / Перфект (Perfect Tense)
grammarNotes.content: The perfect tense (има-perfect) describes completed actions with present relevance, or actions in the indefinite past. It is formed with "има/нема" + past participle (or сум + л-form). This tense often indicates reported or witnessed events, common in narratives and news.
examples: Немам видено. - I have not seen.
Таа има заминато. - She has left.
Тој има научено многу. - He has learned a lot.

grammarNotes.title: Прилози (адверби)
grammarNotes.content: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. Types include manner (брзо, полека), time (сега, утре), place (тука, таму), and degree (многу, малку). Most are invariable.

grammarNotes.title: Честички (партикули)
grammarNotes.content: Particles are small invariable words that modify meaning. Key particles: да (for da-construction), ќе (future), би (conditional), не (negation), ли (question), нека (let), дури/само (only).
translatedExamples: I would like a coffee. would

grammarNotes.title: Именки
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian nouns have three genders (masculine, feminine, neuter) which affect article attachment, adjective agreement, and plural formation. Gender is typically predictable from noun endings.
examples: Многу е лесно да купуваш кога имаш многу пари.
Без да закажеме , нема да нè примат.
За да платите со картичка, повелете на другата каса!
Пред да се зачлените , размислете добро!
Ќе платите откако ќе го доставиме производот.
Дополнете ги речениците со соодветните форми за индиректен предмет.
translatedExamples: It is very easy to buy when you have a lot of money.
Without making an appointment, they will not accept us.
To pay by card, go to the other cash desk!
You will pay after we deliver the product.
They made a mistake while ordering.
Complete the sentences with the appropriate indirect object forms.

chapters.intro: Dream job or reality? Discuss professions and career paths using the perfect tense, adverbs, and particles. Learn to narrate your professional journey and talk about work experiences.

chapters.title: Lesson 6: Светот на дланка

grammarNotes.title: Минато-идно време
grammarNotes.content: Future-in-past (ќе + imperfect) expresses planned future actions from a past perspective. Used in reported speech and narratives to describe what was going to happen.
translatedExamples: He thought he was going to leave.
I knew I would make it.
We were hoping it would rain.
She said she was going to cook.

grammarNotes.title: Нереален услов
grammarNotes.content: Unreal conditional expresses hypothetical or contrary-to-fact situations using "ако" + би + L-form in both clauses. Describes impossible or unlikely scenarios.
examples: Ако би имал пари, би купил куќа.
Ако би знаела, би ти кажала.
Ако би бил поумен, би разбрал.
Би патувал ако би имал време.
translatedExamples: If I had money, I would buy a house.
If I were here, I would help.
If I knew, I would tell you.
If I could, I would come.
If I were smarter, I would understand.
I would travel if I had time.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголска има-конструкција
grammarNotes.content: The ima-construction (има + passive participle) creates perfect passive meaning, emphasizing completed state. Often interchangeable with sum-construction but adds nuance of completion.
examples: Употребете ја во речениците глаголската форма за минато неопределено време (перфект) со значење на прекажаност.
translatedExamples: There were twelve of us at the interview.
Use in the sentences the verb form for the past indefinite tense (perfect) with the meaning of past tense.
His daughter chose a beautiful profession.

grammarNotes.title: Извици (интерјекции)
grammarNotes.content: Interjections are exclamatory words expressing emotions. They stand alone or at the start of sentences. Common ones: ох/ах (surprise), еј (attention), море (emphatic), леле (surprise/dismay).
examples: Таму каде што може, заменете им го и местото во реченицата.
translatedExamples: Where possible, change their place in the sentence as well.

grammarNotes.title: Броеви
grammarNotes.content: Ordinal numbers in Macedonian are adjectives and agree in gender with the noun. Formed by adding -в/-ва/-во (first), -ри/-ра/-ро (second), or -ти/-та/-то for larger numbers.

chapters.intro: The world at your fingertips! Learn the past-future tense for reported speech, unreal conditionals for hypotheticals, and the 'има-construction'. Perfect for discussing travel, technology, and global topics.

chapters.title: Lesson 7: Празнуваме, одбележуваме, честитаме, подаруваме...

grammarNotes.title: Можен услов
grammarNotes.content: Possible conditional expresses unlikely but theoretically possible conditions. Uses imperfect in the condition and би + L-form in the result. For hypothetical future scenarios.
translatedExamples: If he came, I would be happy.
If they asked me, I would say.
If it rained, I wouldn't go out.
If I got money, I would travel.
If he knew, he would understand.
If you were here, you would see.

grammarNotes.title: Глаголски прилог
grammarNotes.content: The verbal adverb (formed with -јќи) describes an action simultaneous with the main verb. Equivalent to English "-ing" forms as adverbs. Invariable and modifies the main action.
examples: Заменете ги овие форми со соодветниот состав од сврзник и глаголска форма за време и препишете ги речениците.
Сношти, бидејќи/додека брзав на излегување од такси, заборавив да ти кажам нешто.
Сношти, брзајќи на излегување од такси, заборавив да ти кажам нешто.
Мислејќи дека овде ќе немаме време, во Љубљана купивме подарок, без гајле!
translatedExamples: Replace these forms with the appropriate combination of conjunction and verb tense and rewrite the sentences.
Last night, as I was rushing out of the taxi, I forgot to tell you something.
Last night, rushing out of the taxi, I forgot to tell you something.
Thinking that we won't have time here, we bought a gift in Ljubljana, never mind!

grammarNotes.title: Пасивни реченици (Passive Voice)
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian passive voice is formed with "е/се" + past participle or with the reflexive particle "се". The participle agrees in gender and number with the subject. Passive constructions are less common in Macedonian than in English; active voice with "се" (reflexive passive) is often preferred.
examples: Книгата е напишана. - The book is written.
Работата е завршена. - The work is finished.
Се продава куќа. - A house is being sold.
Тоа се гледа. - That is seen.
Писмото беше испратено. - The letter was sent.

grammarNotes.title: Предлози
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian prepositions indicate spatial, temporal, and abstract relationships. Key prepositions: во (in), на (on/at), со (with), од (from), за (for), до (to/until), по (after/along).
translatedExamples: The book is on the table.

grammarNotes.title: Броеви
grammarNotes.content: Ordinal numbers in Macedonian are adjectives and agree in gender with the noun. Formed by adding -в/-ва/-во (first), -ри/-ра/-ро (second), or -ти/-та/-то for larger numbers.

chapters.intro: Celebrate, commemorate, congratulate, and gift! Master conditional sentences, verbal adverbs, and passive constructions. Learn the language of holidays, traditions, and special occasions in Macedonia.

chapters.title: Lesson 8: Најди време!

grammarNotes.title: Предминато време (плусквамперфект)
grammarNotes.content: The pluperfect describes an action completed before another past action. Formed with imperfect of "сум" (бев, беше...) + L-form. Used to establish sequence of past events.
examples: Се подготвуваат за викендот во текот на последниот работен ден во неделата.
Поставуваат јасни граници кога станува збор за технологијата.
Поминуваат време со семејството и пријателите.
translatedExamples: They plan their activities in advance.
They prepare for the weekend during the last working day of the week.
They set clear boundaries when it comes to technology.
They shut themselves off from the outside world.
They spend time with family and friends.

grammarNotes.title: Сврзници (конјункции)
grammarNotes.content: Conjunctions connect words, phrases, or clauses. Coordinating: и (and), а/но (but), или (or). Subordinating: дека/оти (that), ако (if), кога (when), затоа што (because).
translatedExamples: I want to, but I can't. (but)

grammarNotes.title: Пресказ
grammarNotes.content: Reported speech conveys what someone said indirectly. In Macedonian, perfect tense often replaces aorist for hearsay. Verbs like "рече дека", "кажа дека" introduce reported clauses.
examples: Родителите на Елена ги поканија сите.
На забавата се пееја песни и се играа ора.
translatedExamples: Songs were sung and dances performed at the party.
The exhibition was opened by the curator.

grammarNotes.title: Броеви (Numbers)
grammarNotes.content: Macedonian numbers 1 and 2 have gender forms that must agree with the noun. Еден/една/едно (one) and два/две (two) change based on the gender of the noun they modify. Numbers from 3 onwards are the same for all genders. After numbers 2-4, nouns take plural form; after 5+, they also take plural.

chapters.intro: Find time for advanced grammar! Tackle the pluperfect tense for events before other past events, conjunctions for complex sentences, and reported speech. The capstone lesson for A2 proficiency.
